description.p: The Eye of the Hand is a pendant, measuring 3 inches wide and 4 inches tall, made of finely carved amber and chased in silver. There is an eye-shaped hole in the center of the palm through which one may look. Doing so will reveal the mark of the Amber Hand which denotes the order's safehouses.
When worn, this amulet grants the wearer advantage on one Sleight of Hand or Survival Skill Check once per day.

This simple and unadorned game bag holds the unique power of being able to preserve any food placed within it indefinitely. The bag has a capacity of 10 lbs of food but never weighs more than 1 pound.
This is a Citrine gem as large as a nectarine held in plain matrix rock and set as a necklace on an iron chain.

When wielded by one with the spellcasting ability, the gem is capable of modifying the memories and thoughts of virtually any target. Additionally, it allows the caster to find their target anywhere (as long as the spell remains active).

The user takes an attack action and spends one charge to attempt to modify a memory. The caster must be touching the target. A spent charge is lost even if the target resists. The gem can hold up to 3 charges at a time. The target must succeed on a wisdom save against your spell save DC + 3 or be subject to whatever memory or thought modifications the caster desires for the spell's duration or until the spell is broken by another. The table below shows the duration of the gem's effects.
Once a target has been affected by the stone's power, they can be easily located by the caster of thier spell for as long as the spell is active, even if the caster no longer wields the gem.
The gem can be recharged at any time by spending spell slots of 3rd level or higher. One slot per charge. Duration of the gem's effects is determined by the level of the slot used to charge it.
This stew uses only the best rodent meat, along with potatoes, carrot, onion, turnip, kale, barley, salt, thyme, rosemary, and black pepper, to provide a tasty and hearty culinary experience.
Eating this stew during a short or long rest grants the following benefits: 5 temporary hit points, resistance to disease and advantage on constitution saving throws. These effects last 1 hour.
Once prepared, this stew may be eaten only out of combat and it requires 10 minutes of downtime.
The stew will keep without refridgeration for up to 2 days.

This ceramic jug appears to be able to hold a gallon of liquid and weighs 12 pounds whether full or empty. Sloshing sounds can be heard from within the jug when it is shaken, even if the jug is empty.

You can use an action and "spend" a single portion of any liquid placing it inside the Jug and replacing the cork. After one minute, you can uncork the jug as an action and pour that liquid out, up to 2 gallons per minute until the maximum for that liquid has been reached. The maximum amount of liquid the jug can produce depends on the liquid you placed within it.
Once the jug starts producing a liquid, it can't produce a different one, or more of one that has reached its maximum, until the next dawn.
Below is a chart for reference. The final decision regarding the maximum amount of a given liquid is made by the DM.
This beautifully made pair of boots are so comfortable and perfectly fit that the wearer's movement is increased by 5 feet.

This ordinary looking cookpot grants all who eat a meal cooked in it 10 temporary hit points plus advantage on death saving throws and any saving throws to resist poison damage or effects. It also grants immunity to disease.
Using this pot's effects drains its magic until the next dawn.
A small statue, well-carved, in the shape of a bird of prey. As an action, the wielder of this stone may grant themselves, or another, the ability to fly and speak to all birds and bats for 1 minute.
Use of the stone's power also grants the target advantage on dexterity saving throws for the duration.
The stone may be used only once per day and it recharges at dawn.

This small, roughly hewn, figure evokes the spirit of a great bear such as a Polar/Cave bear (think Grizzly or Kodiak when thinking of a "cave" bear). The stone's wielder may use an action to imbue themselves with the endurance and speed of a bear for a time.
Use of this stone's power increases the wielder's speed by 10 for 1 minute and grants advantage on strength and constitution saving throws for the duration.
The stone may be used only once per day and it recharges at dawn.

This is an intricately carved statuette of a boar. While wielding the stone, an action may be spent to summon forth a spectral giant boar for one minute that will fight for the wielder and their allies.
The stone may be used only once per day and it recharges at dawn.

This poorly named figurine is nonetheless beautifully carved in the shape of a giant spider. As an action, the wielder of the "insect" stone may grant themselves or another the ability to envenomate enemies when striking them for 1 minute. The condition lasts until a constitution save of DC 15 ends it.

On each successful hit, the envenomated enemy suffers 1d6 poison damage. The effect of this venom is cumulative however. Therefore the first hit deals 1d6 poison and each successive hit deals and additional 1d6 until the target dies or the condition ends.
The stone may be used only once per day and it recharges at dawn.
A simply carved small statue of a Rat. While wielding the statue you may spend an action to grant yourself or another the resourcefulness of rats for one minute.
Using this stone's power grants the target advantage on ability checks to climb a surface and on all survival ability checks.
The target also gains the rat's ability to dodge, imposing disadvantage on any attack roll made against them and granting advantage on dexterity saving throws.
The stone may be used only once per day and it recharges at dawn.

For 1 minute, any enemy who enters your aura must make a wisdom save at a DC equal to 8 + your strength modifier + your proficiency bonus or become frightned. A frightned enemy may roll a save at the end of each of their turns to against this condition.

description.p: You may now use your Emissary of Peace class feature in combat.

As an action, you may roll a Charisma(Persuasion) check, contested by your target's Wisdom or Intelligence abilities, against an enemy you can see and make a plea for the enemy to leave the field. If you are successful, the enemy ceases fighting (and all sustained effects) immediately and retires from the battle. This enemy will not engage further so long as they are not attacked from that point (they WILL defend themselves). If the attempt fails, the target is immune to the ability for 24 hours.
Once used, this ability may not be used again until you finish a long rest.

description.p: You may integrate a number of pieces of equipment equal to half your mystic level (rounded down) into your frame. This equipment may be either magical or normal however no item requiring attunement may be integrated.
Integration offers the following effects:

ul.li: The piece of equipment cannot be damaged or removed from your possession.
The weight of integrated equipment is considered to be 0 for purposes of determining encumbrance and carry limits.
The integrated equipment answers to your thoughts and may therefore be called up or accessed (as in a backpack or bag of holding), with a free move action (just like drawing a weapon is).

sheet.description: You may integrate {{level:mystic:half}} items, not requiring attunement, into your frame.

description.p: You have advantage on initiative rolls. In addition, you and any of your companions within 30 feet of you can't be surprised, except when incapacitated by something other than nonmagical sleep. The weapon magically awakens you and your companions within range if any of you are sleeping naturally when combat begins.

description.p: Once per short rest, you may use an attack action to deal 1d10 psychic damage directly to an opponent. You may spend Psi Points to increase this damage, 1 Psychic for each psi point spent to a maximum equal to your Psi Limit.

This attack cannot be avoided by most enemies and therefore hits automatically. However targets that are resistant to psychic damage may make a constitution saving throw to resist the full damage of the attack (otherwise they take half damage as normal.

If this power is used on a target that in immune to psychic damage, the attack rebounds on the attacker. You must make a constitution saving throw against your own Spell Save DC or suffer half damage. A successful save negates all rebound damage.

sheet.description: Deal 1d10 + number of additional Psi Points spent (max. = Psi Limit) psychic damage to an opponent; unblockable.
